definition:
Given base $b$, a number of the form $d({{b^n - 1} \over {b - 1}})$ for
$n > 0$ and $0 < d < b$ is written using using the digit $d$ only, $n$
times in that base and is therefore a [*repdigit*]{}. The term, short
for “repeated digit,” is credited to Beiler’s book [*Recreations in the
theory of numbers*]{}, in chapter 11.

When $d = 1$, the resulting repdigit is called a repunit. Only repunits
can also be prime (and then they are rare). No other repdigit can be
prime since it is obvious that it is a multiple of a repunit.

In a trivial way, all repdigits are palindromic numbers.
